headline: Our Family: Resolved To Be Irresolute
summary: Although the expert advice in "How to Keep a Resolution" (Personal Journal, Dec. 22) to set specific goals, make a detailed plan in advance, practice beforehand and plan to avoid pitfalls sounds convincing, I'm afraid it won't help my family.

summary: James L. Day writes to the WSJ.

summary: What's News: Business & Finance for December 29, 2010.

headline: Death at Soho House Is Ruled Homicide
summary: The New York City medical examiner has determined that the death of swimwear designer Sylvie Cachay, whose body was found in the bathtub of the Soho House earlier this month, was a homicide, officials said Wednesday.

headline: Court Rejects Challenge to Schools Appointment
summary: A state Supreme Court judge in Albany rejected on Wednesday a legal effort to enjoin Mayor Michael Bloomberg from installing Cathie Black, a publishing executive, as New York City's next chancellor.

headline: Police Commissioner in Traffic Accident
summary: A New York Police Department sport-utility vehicle carrying Commissioner Raymond Kelly was involved in a chain-reaction crash on a Brooklyn highway Wednesday.

headline: Man Killed in Barber-Shop Shooting
summary: A shooting at a Queens barber shop early Wednesday left one man dead and another wounded, police said.

headline: Russia Probes Airlines
summary: Russia's top prosecutor singled out five airlines for apparent violations of passenger rights during a near-halt in air traffic at Moscow's two biggest airports this week.

headline: SMFG Plans Growth in New York, London
summary: Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group is gearing up to expand its brokerage business outside Japan by setting up offices and hiring staff in the world's major financial centers, President Teisuke Kitayama said in an interview.

headline: After Hours: Macau
summary: None

headline: BANGKOK CITY WALK: SURPRISES IN THE SHADOWS
summary: None

headline: Factory Worker Inspired Iconic Poster
summary: Geraldine Doyle, who died Sunday at age 86, was a 17-year-old metal-stamping machine operator in 1942 when a United Press photographer snapped a picture that likely became the inspiration for one of the most famous World War II posters.

headline: Financial Briefing Book: Dec. 30
summary: Financial Briefing Book: Dec. 30

headline: U.S. Stocks Add to Strong December
summary: The Dow industrials rose 9.84 points to 11585.38, adding to the measure's gain of more than 5% this month. With two trading days to go, the Dow is up more than 11% for 2010.

headline: Bank Failures at Highest Level Since 1992
summary: More banks failed in 2010 than any year since the savings-and-loan crisis ended in 1992, but regulators said Wednesday that they believe failures have passed their peak.

headline: Running a Business in a Disaster Zone
summary: Think your business had a tough year? A look at the challenges that entrepreneurs faced in the world's more troubled regions, from Iraq to Ireland.

headline: The Day the Folk Music Thrived
summary: Regarding "Better Than the Real Thing?" (Bookshelf, Dec. 18): Many folk singers, who attempt to achieve success by breaking out of the folk pack and fail, take refuge for the rest of their lives in the false theory that popularity automatically equals artistic mediocrity.

headline: A Real Man-Likes-Dogs Story
summary: It isn't just border collies that need a job ("In a Tale That Wags Dog Owners, They Rent Flocks for Bored Collies," page one, Dec. 27).

headline: Snowstorms Delay Sales
summary: East Coast snowstorms shaved about 10% off of retail sales on Sunday and Monday, but the $1 billion in lost sales will likely be made up soon, according to ShopperTrak.

headline: Sinking Under the Weight of Castro
summary: Mary Anastasia O'Grady's "A Cuban Fairy Tale From PBS" (Americas, Dec. 27) reminds me of the last time I spoke with Jose Menendez, a revered engineering professor, colleague, and mentor of mine at the University of Havana.

headline: China Considers Further Rare-Earth Quotas
summary: China is considering issuing export quotas for rare-earth alloys in a bid to further regulate the exports of the minerals used in a variety of high-tech industries.

headline: Let's Stop Taxing Our Children
summary: Municipal unions have made a great mistake of negotiating far-off pension payments with government entities that cannot (and never could) be expected to meet these huge commitments ("Pensions Push Taxes Higher," page one, Dec. 24). Naturally, public-employee union leaders don't want to admit this.

headline: Sorting PolitiFact From Politically Motivated Fiction
summary: So PolitiFact deems that "a government takeover of health care" is a "lie" and we are all to take its word for it (Review & Outlook, "PolitiFiction," Dec. 23)?

headline: Top-Grossing Acts of 2010
summary: As with previous years, older bands and singers dominated the list of top concerts in 2010.

headline: Norilsk, Rusal Battle Intensifies
summary: Norilsk planned to buy back up to $4.5 billion in shares after failing to reach a compromise with shareholders on Rusal's 25% stake.

headline: Seeking Corporate-Tax Cut Balance
summary: All signs suggest that President Obama will seek to lower the corporate-tax rate by eliminating deductions, credits and loopholes, but he's also likely to tell big business to find a way to pay for it, David Wessel writes.

headline: Copper Hovers Near Record
summary: Comex copper futures set another intraday record before pulling back, as prices wavered between breaking new ground and retreating to more familiar levels.

headline: China Embraces Heavy Snow
summary: Parts of China have experienced significant drops in temperatures and heavy snows over the past week, hampering travel.

headline: Vanguard Aims for Detroit Hospital Deal
summary: Vanguard Health Systems and the Detroit Medical Center are racing to complete a final takeover agreement ahead of a Dec. 31 deadline.

headline: European Stocks on Track for One of Year's Best Months
summary: The Stoxx Europe 600 index extended December's gains to 7.2%, almost its best month of the year.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In today's pictures, Turkish army parachutists train, a lemur weighs in at a German zoo, a boat operator brings in his vessel on a misty day in Nepal and more.

headline: Pension Fund Sues Wachovia
summary: A pension fund for Ohio school employees has sued Wachovia and its now-owner Wells Fargo over losses the fund sustained from investing in the Wachovia's securities lending program.

headline: Plains, PAA to Buy Gas Storage Facility
summary: Plains All American Pipeline LP and its natural-gas unit PAA Natural Gas Storage LP agreed to acquire SG Resources Mississippi LLC's salt-cavern natural-gas storage facility for about $750 million.

headline: LSE Says IPOs Rose Six-Fold in 2010
summary: The London Stock Exchange Group said proceeds from initial public offerings in London this year rose more than six times from last year to $15.49 billion.

headline: Nunavut Raises Bid for Baffinland
summary: Canada's Nunavut sweetened its bid for a controlling stake in Baffinland Iron Mines Corp., offering to pay about $272 million to increase its stake to 60%.

headline: Italy on Alert
summary: A bombing and a series of package bombs discovered across Rome over the past week have the police -- and the people -- of Italy's capital on edge.

headline: Gold Holds Above $1,400
summary: Gold finished above $1,400 for a second straight day on fresh investor demand but thin trading.

headline: Groupon Plans Preferred Stock Sale
summary: Daily deals website Groupon is seeking authorization to sell up to $950 million in preferred shares to investors. A sale would value the company at upwards of $7.8 billion.

headline: Pfizer to Acquire Veterinary Diagnostics Firm
summary: Pfizer agreed to acquire privately held Synbiotics, a developer of veterinary diagnostics products.

headline: Corporate Tax Rates: U.S. & Abroad
summary: Corporate tax rates vary substantially around the world, and many big economies have lower rates than the U.S. See a table of more than 20 nations' rates.

headline: NFL Fines Favre $50,000
summary: The NFL has fined Brett Favre for a "failure to cooperate" with the investigation into allegations he sent inappropriate messages and lewd photos to a former New York Jets game-day hostess.

headline: Several Global Indexes Poised for Double-Digit 2010 Gains
summary: Across the world, the recent advances in stocks have many major stock indexes poised for double-digit percentage gains for 2010—particularly those in North America and Europe.

headline: Brazil Finances Fall Deeper Into Red
summary: Brazil's public sector finances fell deeper into the red in November, adding to concerns over spending, inflation and interest rates.

headline: Noble Rallies on Israeli Project
summary: Noble Energy confirmed estimates that its offshore Leviathan gas reserve contains about 16 trillion cubic feet of natural gas, making it Israel's largest energy discovery ever.

headline: Kunlun Buys PetroChina Unit
summary: Kunlun Energy will buy a natural-gas transmission company from PetroChina for $2.85 billion.

headline: Global Warming Grinch
summary: Democratic Senator Robert Menendez's bizarre warning to Santa about the North Pole.

headline: Ex-Lehman Workers Revive Suit
summary: Former Lehman Brothers employees are defending their bid to sue the firm's directors for investing their retirement savings in Lehman stock while the company was disguising its financial condition.

headline: Vietnam to Ease Exchange-Rate Rules
summary: Vietnam will follow a more flexible exchange-rate regime next year while using monetary policy to curb inflation, the central bank said, signaling a possible interest-rate increase and another devaluation of the dong.

headline: New Petrobras Fields Make Their Mark
summary: Petrobras declared Brazil's Tupi and Iracema presalt oil areas commercially viable, with a total recoverable volume of 8.3 billion barrels of oil equivalent.

headline: Shinhan Bank CEO to Resign
summary: Shinhan Bank Chief Executive Lee Baek-soon will step down after being indicted by South Korean prosecutors. He becomes the third executive to resign amid a scandal that rocked the bank and its parent company earlier this year.

headline: Hong Kong, China Rally
summary: Asian stocks ended mostly higher, with Hong Kong and Shanghai markets rebounding from recent declines. Tower Australia surged on a takeover bid from Dai-ichi Life Insurance.

headline: GenVec to Collaborate With Sanofi Unit on Vaccine
summary: GenVec will be working with Sanofi's animal-health unit Merial to commercialize GenVec's vaccine technology for treatment of foot-and-mouth disease.

headline: Honda Recalls 18,500 Snowblowers
summary: Honda Motor is voluntarily recalling about 18,500 snowblowers with fuel-tank parts that can seep or drip fuel, which could cause a fire.

headline: Indian Telecoms Fined for Delayed Rollout
summary: At least three Indian telecommunication companies have paid penalties to the federal government for failing to launch mobile phone services on time.

headline: La ola de calor en Argentina colapsa la red eléctrica y causa recortes de luz
summary: Con la ola de calor que afecta la capital argentina, Buenos Aires, la red eléctrica ha colapsado ante un consumo récord que ha provocado cortes esporádicos del suministro eléctrico y protestas de los acalorados habitantes.

headline: Euro-Zone Corporate  Lending Rebounds
summary: Lending to euro-zone businesses picked up again in November, posting its strongest annual rate of growth in over a year.

headline: U.K. Housing Payments to Hit Spending
summary: U.K. households continued to pay back equity into their homes in the third quarter of 2010, the Bank of England said, reducing the amount available for homeowners to spend.

headline: Telecom Firms Pay Penalty for Delayed Rollout
summary: At least three Indian telecommunication companies--Etisalat DB Telecom, Loop Telecom and Unitech Wireless -- have paid a penalty to the federal government for the delayed launch of mobile telephony services.

headline: RBI Eases Forex Rules
summary: India's central bank issued rules to allow Indian companies to continue using zero cost structures in over-the-counter derivative foreign exchange trading.

headline: A Peaceful Somali Enclave Seeks New Business
summary: Entrepreneurs and officials in Somaliland, a relatively peaceful, autonomous region in northern Somalia, are touting their gains as a model of stability while southern Somalia wrestles with virtual anarchy.

headline: German Consumer Prices Surge
summary: Consumer prices in Germany rose by more in December than in the previous eight months put together, according to Destatis.

headline: Allstate Sues Countrywide Over Toxic Investments
summary: Insurance company Allstate sued mortgage-originator Countrywide Financial, now a part of Bank of America, over $700 million in residential mortgage-backed securities that the insurer had invested in.

headline: Patni Board Likely to Meet on Bid Next Week
summary: Patni's board is likely to meet early next week to consider a joint bid by Apax Partners and iGate to buy a controlling stake in the company, three people familiar with the matter said.

headline: India Wins Durban Test
summary: India beat South Africa by 87 runs in the second test match in Durban Wednesday to level the three-test series. Some snapshots.

headline: India Minister: Final Decision on POSCO Project by January-End

headline: Skanska Sells Stake in Chilean Highway
summary: Swedish construction firm Skanska said it is selling its 50% stake in the Autopista Central highway in Chile for a gain of $727.5 million.

headline: England Retains Ashes
summary: England has retained the Ashes by completing an innings and 157-run win over Australia on the fourth day of the fourth cricket test.

headline: India Sets New Renewable Energy Target
summary: India plans to quadruple its power generation capacity from renewable sources to 72,400 megawatts by 2022.

headline: Chevron Gives DJIA Fuel
summary: The Dow industrials rose slightly as Chevron and H-P shares gained. The Dow is up 11% for the year-to-date with three trading days left.

headline: Norilsk, Rusal Fail to Agree on Buyout Price
summary: Shareholders in Russian miner OAOfailed to find a compromise on the buyout of one of their stakes, prolonging a two-year old conflict.

headline: Corporate India This Year
summary: From Bharti's multi-billion dollar deal with Kuwait's Zain to the Hero-Honda split: a year of Indian business, in pictures.

summary: India announced a raft of measures, including the sale of additional grains at subsidized rates and maintaining a ban on pulse exports, to help consumers grapple with high food prices.

headline: Faces of Foreclosure: Twice Hit

summary: A slick new musical with Broadway-style production values is poised to test China's sensitivity to criticism.

headline: Chinese Web Retailer Attracts Investment
summary: China's 360buy.com raised more than $500 million from Wal-Mart and other investors, the latest sign that competition is heating up in China's online retail sector.

headline: Following a Natural Script
summary: Print Restaurant is the perfect spot for a private meeting with a business client. Because it's in a hotel dining room, there's also room for larger gatherings.

summary: Big U.S. banks are starting to increase lending to businesses as demand for loans rises and healthier banks seek to grab customers from rivals.

headline: Yen's Gain Worsens Government Woes

headline: Food for Thought in India
summary: India should use the money raised from the sale of state assets to improve its food security. Not doing so poses a threat to the country's economic future.

summary: The renowned Italian ice cream has its own "university" that is attracting thousands of would-be gelatieri drawn by the allure of serving a product that people love to eat.

headline: Copper Again in Record Territory
summary: Copper prices marched into uncharted territory as a weaker dollar and investor appetite for commodities brushed away concerns about the impact of China's weekend interest-rate hike.

summary: A growing number of small-business owners are expected to try cloud computing services next year, hoping to trim costs and stay up and running if disaster strikes.

headline: Pizza Chain Seeks Slice of Bicultural Pie
summary: Pizza Patrón, a 100-unit restaurant chain that has long catered to a Spanish-speaking clientele, is turning its charms on English speakers.

summary: As Republicans prepare to assume control of the House next week, they aren't in as big a rush to privatize mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, cautioning that withdrawing government support in the housing market should be gradual.

summary: The hurdles to building a golf course in Greece speak to the country's broader economic problems.

summary: New Year's Eve is almost here, but don't let that stop you from making some important money moves now, before Dec. 31, so you can reap the benefits in 2011.

summary: World-wide spending on oil and natural gas exploration and development is projected to hit a record next year in a sign of the energy industry's confidence that high crude prices won't fall and may go higher.

summary: India, one of the hottest destinations for global investors in 2010, is engaged in a debate over how its stock exchanges will be listed and regulated.

summary: Public support for terrorism is still dropping in Islamic countries, but more slowly than it did during the Bush years.

summary: Pushed to raise cash by a recent modification of a $2.7 billion loan, Boston-based Beacon Capital Partners is poised to sell its most valuable asset in a 20-property portfolio of office buildings in Washington, D.C., and Seattle.

summary: A band of Internet rivals is joining together in hopes of jump-starting sales of online ads to local businesses, and of defending their turf in the emerging local-ad market from Google.

summary: The best that can probably be hoped for is that housing in 2011 manages to bounce along the bottom, rather than plumb new lows.

headline: FDA Commissioner: Agency Is World-Class Regulator

summary: Vicious winds set back efforts to restore air travel as New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg responded to charges that his administration was slow to respond to a blizzard that snarled traffic and left many passengers stranded at airports.

summary: Iran is stepping up pressure on dissidents, executing two political prisoners Tuesday and arresting more than a dozen Kurdish activists this week.

summary: What a euroyear it has been. The show opened with a Greek tragedy and is closing with, well, a eurofarce.

summary: India has tightened the web of sanctions around Iran by barring Indian companies from a range of deals transacted through a key trade-finance clearinghouse.

summary: One of the most over-the-top invitations to arrive this year—via FedEx, of course—is for this weekend's opening of the Cosmopolitan Hotel in Las Vegas, where Jay-Z and Coldplay are scheduled to perform.

headline: Since When Do the Phillies Outspend the Mets?
summary: A great deal of Philadelphia's money has gone to homegrown players and those acquired in trade, while the Mets have spent enormous sums on the generally underwhelming likes of Jason Bay, Luis Castillo and Francisco Rodriguez.

summary: Health insurers are preparing to capitalize on new opportunities to run privately managed Medicaid plans for the states.

summary: News that regulators need more time to review MannKind's inhaled insulin product spurred options traders into positions that profit if the biopharmaceutical company's stock slides.

summary: Ivory Coast's incumbent President Laurent Gbagbo said that his government would cut diplomatic ties with countries that follow a call issued by his opponent, Alassane Ouattara, for the removal of the country's ambassadors.

summary: The SEC is examining the trading of shares in privately held companies, including Facebook and Twitter, as such activity has surged in the past year.

summary: What a euroyear it has been. The show opened with a Greek tragedy and is closing with, well, a eurofarce.

summary: The 3D Reality: There is no guarantee 3D programming will ever become as widespread as HD. Those hoping for a faster takeoff of 3D could be left feeling, well, flat.

summary: Indian police filed a case against an employee of the local unit of Citigroup and three other people after the bank reported some "suspicious transactions."

summary: When screening a fund manager, investors like to see experience and a consistent record or returns. But some are turning to professional lie detectors as they look to avoid the next Madoff.

summary: Late rally cuts 22-point deficit to three before Miami prevails behind's Wade's 36.

summary: Right guard Chris Snee, center Shaun O'Hara, safety Antrel Rolle and defensive end Justin Tuck were all selected to the Pro Bowl.

summary: More Americans are making space for saunas, clearing out basements, converting closets and even partitioning off backyard sheds to accommodate the hot rooms.

summary: The fiber-optic network business is enjoying a resurgence, particularly for the high-capacity lines that connect a city's office buildings, data centers and cellular towers to the Internet.

summary: The father-son team behind Xi'an Famous Foods has four postage-size restaurants and plans for many more.

summary: Here are 10 inviolate rules to follow to make this sport everything it needs to be.
